title: big night in short on laughs
story: And there’s a very real possibility ITV won’t be able to make any murder mysteries, set in quiet and unsuspecting English seaside towns, for at least another  months.With so many things going right for viewers, in lockdown, it was inevitable television’s revenge would be fairly prolonged and unforgiving when it came, on Thursday evening.BBC’s The Big Night In, a pm-pm collaboration between Comic Relief and Children In Need, where they were keen to observe the Government’s social-distancing rules and the BBC rule that states there can never be fewer than three presenters at a charity event, no matter the size of the catastrophe or studio .It started then with Matt Baker, Lenny Henry, who was often left heckling off-screen, and Davina McCall, who was over-selling absolutely everything.All three of them, plus Zoe Ball and Paddy McGuinness, who turned up to relieve the -: sht, had a list of threats as well.“The cast of EastEnders quiz each other.” “Greg James brings us viral videos.” “Theof Miranda.” “Gary Barlow sings with special guests,” and “David Walliams, is here with a money-can’t-buy prize,” which turned out to be a namecheck in his next book and a lot of self-promotion.“But first up,” Davina continued, “a song that’s more poignant than ever.”China In Your Hand by T’Pau  No, worse. It’s the patron saint of snowflakes, Sam Smith singing Lay Me Down.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Once that was done, the sheer scale of The Big Night In’s assault became clear.Because the viewers never escape undamaged on these occasions. For every Peter Kay, who you want to see, there are three members of The Mash Report team, who you really don’t. There are also corporate sponsors to satisfy and a surprise appearance from Prince William, in a Blackadder spin-off sketch, with Stephen Fry, asking: “Have you seen anything good on TV ” .On the face of it then, it looked impossible to separate the wheat from all that celebrity chaff.In reality, though, it was surprisingly easy, because lockdown TV has already taught us song and dance can still work, even on Skype,the artists are as good as Dave Grohl and the others, who collaborated on Times Like These, or as talented and attractive as the Strictly professionals.Just as obviously, we’ve learned to rely on the internet for laughs this past month, because television comedy isn’t anywhere near funny enough to see us through a crisis. Thursday night wasn’t ever going to change that opinion, but it did highlight a ide.Eventhey were phoning in the performances, there were a group of comedians some viewers will have been excited to see, like Coogan, Brydon, Dawn French, Little Britain etc, who all had careers before . And there were a group of comedians who’ve been forced on us, since then, who aren’t comedians at all. At best, they’re pub-funny show-offs — at worst they’re political propagandists trying to bend us to their will.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.The contrast could not have been better illustrated by the segment where modern Mash Report types and old-school stand-ups were given about ten seconds to make us laugh and the only one who could nail it was Tim Vine, who appeared with a placard reading “Bad” and a punchline: “That’s not a good sign is it.”An actual punchline! On the BBC! It’s one of the many things that’s been missing from the network, for years, though I was glad long-suffering viewers didn’t punish TBNI for past failures. Thursday was hardly the time for mass recriminations.At some point in the future, though, someone has to try to explain to the BBC that we prefer comedians who make us laugh rather than tell us off, andthere was a reason why The Big Night In seemed less wearying and slightly more uplting than the usual Comic Relief slog then, beyond the extraordinary circumstances, it was a very obvious one.It only lasted three hours. Less is more, guys.TV astrologer Russell Grant made this uncanny  prediction, for those of us born in the star sign Cancer, late last year, in the Mirror.“Travel is on the cards in the spring and as much as you enjoy your home le, you will appreciate this change of scene.”Yeah, the Sainsbury’s queue was a blast, thanks Russ.“It’s not just The Big Night In, April  is, of course . . .”A St George’s Day B Shakespeare’s birthday C Darren Huckerby’s birthday It was D “The start of Ramadan.”The clue being in the letters BBC, of course.THE Dave channel has been attempting to ease the nation’s ever-present mental health worries via the gt of laughter.A noble cause and a good idea.Unfortunately, they’ve given the all-important job to some of the worst comedians in Britain.Last week, it was the turn of Nish Kumar, Suzi Ruffell, Seann Walsh and Darren Harriott, whose attempts to end Britain’s silent suffering were ided into two separate and contrasting segments.In the first, backstage, they discussed their own experiences of mental health issues, which sounded more like a lot of really bad hangovers, egotism and self-pity, while making the usual heartfelt pleas for tolerance, understanding and a constructive dialogue.’Cos, you know, they’re alive to the fact they’re meant to care.Then Kumar and Ruffell went out on stage and spewed vile, angry foul-mouthed hatred about Boris, Trump, Top Gear, Richard Hammond , fellow comedians and anyone who’s got what Ruffell calls “lazy opinions”.That is to say, anyone who has the temerity to hold a dferent political opinion to her own.Not a single word of it was funny, let alone healing.Darren Harriott, the least worst of them, though, did at least have the decency to provide the necessary cue.“I struggle to give people all of me ’cos I’m always worried they’re going to go, they’re going to disappear and . . .”Click.He’s got a point, hasn’t he.Paul Merson: “Bournemouth seem to keep coming up without answers.”Micah Richards: “The way he carried his body language was outstanding.”Matt Le Tissier: “Spurs are never going to win the league in a million years. Not at the moment anyway.”.IT was mild-mannered Jack Maynard who summed up John Fashanu’s many foibles best, after the former footballer had tried throttling DJ Locksmith on Channel ’s Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins.“Number four,” he said, with some feeling, “is a t**t.” He is indeed. He’s not the only one on that show, either. There’s strong competition to be the biggest one from Bluto-ish oaf Tony Bellew, the former world cruiserweight boxing champion, who’s got an even shorter fuse than Fashanu.Both have already been called in for fairly urgent “questioning” by the SAS instructors who always hold the whip hand during these interrogations as, at the first hint of vanity, derangement, pretension or self-delusion, Ant Middleton can shout “GUARD!” and Billy bundles them off with a hood over their head.If it was just a hardman staring contest, of course, the show wouldn’t work. But it’s not. Sometimes the Special Forces team are staring at contestants like “YouTuber” Jack Maynard, trying to get their heads around what the hell it is he actually does for a living.“I will come up with some video idea and I direct, film, edit and present the thing myself.”Billy : “So you’re actually a smart f***er.”There are also emerging friendships, hidden tensions, a lot of honest endeavour and a simmering feud between Paralympian Lauren Steadman and Joey Essex, which erupts on next week’s show .SAS: Who Dares Wins will have to proceed, though, without Katie Price, who quit after a feeble two-day effort, and Anthea Turner, who tried getting all philosophical just before she threw in her armband. “I feel I am in what the Japanese call my second spring.”Fetch the hood, Billy.MEANWHILE, over on episode two of I’ll Get This, Jermaine Jenas says to Sara Pascoe: “I’ll be waiting for the comedian in you to come out.”So we’ll check up on him again in November .C’s SAS: Who Dares Wins. Brilliant Diane “Kath” Morgan providing the one believable newspaper office character on After Le.Race Across the World’s only likeable pair, Emon and Jamiul, beating “highly strung” Jen and Rob by just  seconds in the show’s final leg. Vintage Britain’s Got Talent eccentric Bhim Niroula getting the entire London Palladium singing along to Every Day I Love You. And Sophie Raworth’s fitting One Show tribute to the great Lynn Faulds Wood.To her absolute core, a journalist who improved people’s lives.Sean: “.”Beat The Chasers, Bradley Walsh: “In  ­Parisian waiters went on strike to demand better pay, more time off and the right to grow what ”Cha: “Onions.”Tenable, Warwick Davis: “We’re looking for the names of the ten woodwind and brass instruments played by the BBC philharmonic orchestra.”Bryan: “It’s a lightbulb moment . . . violin.”.BIG Night In host Davina McCall claiming “We’re presenting this in the safest possible way,” while flanked by two other presenters, in a very small studio.The second series of Ricky Gervais’ Netflix series After Le trying far too hard to push our emotional buttons and shock us. The entire Amsterdam police department speaking fluent Mockney on ITV’s new version of Van Der Valk.Angry young comedians still failing to understand they’ll never say anything funnier than whatever bats**t crazy thing Donald Trump has just said. And Nish Kumar actually wondering out loud, on Comedy Against Living Miserably, : “Periods of depression are linked to my career ” Yes, directly.ON the first episode of ITVBe’s Gemma Collins: Diva On Lockdown, the Brentwood Morlock split her dress at a Prince’s Trust gig, troubled mum, Joan, showed worrying signs she was developing “a bad pain in the butt area”, after giving birth to another one  years ago, and on a visit to her local bathroom supplier, Gemma asked: “Is there a machine that can dry me getting out of the bath ”Not this side of the Humber Gateway wind turbine field, there isn’t, Gemma. But give Boeing a call.They’d be grateful for the work. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus doctors long term effects covid
story: THE sight of brave coronavirus survivors cheered on by NHS staff as they leave hospital has been a rare ray of sunshine during the deadly pandemic.But, while Boris Johnson was back at work two weeks after being discharged, the road to recovery is a long one for some sufferers - with many heading home in wheelchairs and reporting lingering issues such as brain fog.The symptoms of Covid- - including fever, coughing and shortness of breath - are now well-known, but the long-term effects of the illness are still unknown.Dr James Gill, a GP locum and clinical lecturer at Warwick university, has treated Covid patients both before and after hospitalisation.He tells Sun Online: After  days needing help with breathing, possibly on a ventilator and sedated, we can’t just say, ‘you’ve won the battle, back to the world you go.’Patients are going to need step-down care, with nutritionists getting them to eat well and physios helping them to mobilise again.Here, two experts reveal the symptoms recovering patients may need to look out for - from memory loss to dizziness - and how they can best aid theirto normal le.Survivors of Covid- have testied it can take days and weeks to get back on their feet.Boris Johnson had to regain his mobility by taking short walks in hospital between long periods of rest, while another patient discharged from Torbay hospital this week recorded loss of muscle mass and a lack of energy.For the worst cases of Covid-, where patients in Intensive Care Unitsare on ventilators, and often put into a medical coma, recovery will be slow.Dr Gill says physiotherapy will be required to get many survivors mobile again. “Most people who complete a half marathon wouldnt want to do another one the following day, because of how much it hurts, he says.  But getting through the worst cases of the Covid- virus, and the effect it has on your body, is like doing a half marathon every day during your time in ICU. It is a colossal assault on the body.You are physically put through the wringer so the recovery process, depending on your age and fitness level, is going to be a slow process.Patients will suffer from fatigue, in the same way that somebody runs over the marathon line, then collapses and their legs turn to jelly, and they may need help learning how to walk again.After she and husband Tom Hanks recovered from the virus, Rita Wilson admitted she was suffering from brain fog and memory loss, and a muddled brain has also been flagged as a symptom to watch out for, along with headaches.Your brain is unlikely to be starved of oxygen while on a ventilator and, when struggling to breathe, the body prioritises oxygen to the brain, shutting down other organs first, so its unlikely to suffer permanent damage.But Dr Bharat Pankhania, an expert in infectious diseases who has advised on previous SARS and Ebola pandemics, says nerve damage could affect your brain .It is well known that the coronavirus can harm or affect the kidneys, but it may also have an effect on the central nervous system, he says.Its important to watch out for new signs and symptoms which are unusual, such as headaches, dizziness, vertigo and tingling.Although being on a ventilator means your brain wont have been starved of oxygen, it is very important to watch out for what we call ‘deficit’ - meaning memory loss, the brain working a little bit slower than before, impaired speech or any other signs that the central nervous system has been affected.You should consult a doctorany of these occur.As the virus affects the lungs, and leads to viral pneumonia, there could be permanent damage to the lung tissue.This means shortness of breath will continue for weeks after leaving hospital.Theof time it takes to recover from a severe bout of Covid- will depend on the patient, Dr Gill says.As a -year-old triathlete,I ended up in ICU, I would hope to recover in terms of straightforward mobility within three to six weeksBut lets take Mrs. Bloggs, who is  and doesnt have a particularly active lestyle. I would expect it to take a lot longer - months more than weeks.In survivors of SARS, which also caused breathing dficulties,  to  per cent were still reporting reduced exercise tolerance and X-rays showed evidence of lung changes,  months after the infection.What we have seen of Covid- so far, even people whove had mild to moderate symptoms are still finding they are short of breath three to four weeks later, Dr Gill adds.Colleagues who had mild symptoms told me it took two weeks before they could walk up three or four steps without stopping for breath. And these are fit young people.But everything about this virus is unpredictable. We had a patient at the surgery who has a lot of respiratory problems and was in hospital for other things when she contracted coronavirus.I would have bet money we would lose that patient but, thankfully, she wasn’t badly affected at all.She had a bit of a cough and has gone home now. I was absolutely astonished.We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.While people will all recover at dferent rates, going back to work or starting to exercise too early could seriously hamper progress, says Dr Pankhania.The virus causes inflammation in the lungs and the air sacs become very inflamed, red, raw and wounded, he explains.Recovery starts when the patient is able to breathe properly by themselves and when the inflammation is subdued.But for the repair process to work, the patient has to allow the body to recuperate, and that means rest and sleep.Dr Pankhania says it would be unwise for somebody who has had a viral pneumonia to get back to full activities straight away, especiallyit entails strenuous work, because youre not allowing the healing process to take time.How long that process takes is very inidual. For some people, its very rapid, inside two weeks, but for some it might go on for six to eight weeks.Whatever your fitness level, I would suggest at least three months rest from strenuous exercise because this inflammatory process can be simmering away.If you ran k before the illness, pace yourself and build up very gently. First do a mile, then two and so on.As well as the physical effects of the coronavirus, many patients will suffer mentally in recovery.Being close to death, and often delirious in intensive care, can be the most traumatic experience of a survivors le  and can lead to depression, anxiety, post traumatic stress disorder and other mental health issues.A  study of nearly , UK ICU survivors found that over half had developed at least one of these conditions a year after they leaving hospital.If you have had a tube down your throat to help you breathe, its not unusual for that to have a signicant psychological impact, Dr Gill explains.Even patients who have had the moderate coronavirus have told me they wake at night in a panic, terried because theyve been dreaming they cant breathe.Theres been a huge amount of funding and support and everybody has stood up and said, ‘we need to treat people who are sick with Covid-’. Yes, without a shadow of a doubt that was the right thing to do.But my worry is whether the nutritionists, the physiotherapists and the psychologists will have the funding to help these people afterwards.Rest, sleep and a healthy diet are the key to a full recovery, says Dr Pankhania, and he advises survivors not to rush back to work.People ought not to feel pressurised toto work when they are still feeling unwell or theyre exhibiting signs and symptoms of illness, he says.It is a well-known fact that good nutrition is very important to the recovery process, as is sleep.Smoking will impede the repair process and so will too much exercise.It is also important to avoid secondary infections in the lungs, which can have a severe consequences, so keeping up to date with flu jabs and pneumococcal vaccines, for those who are at risk, is essential.For the majority of Covid- sufferers, there is unlikely to be any long term damage, but Dr Pankhania says they should be on the lookout for anything unusual.Looking at other severe infections, I would expect most patients to make a full recovery with no after effects, he says.But it is still important to be watchful for signs and symptoms, because with any signicant infection, sometimes people are left with a long term deficits.”However, there may be some complications that are unpredictable.This is a new virus and we had no concept this even existed in October last year, so a lot of research is being done very, very quickly by the wonderful lab technicians, microbiologists and the scientists, to scale up testing and help us combat this, says Dr Gill.We are learning about Covid as we go along and it’s safe to say it would not be surprisingsome patients had a long term effects as a result of the virus. We simply don’t know.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: contact tracing program ease lockdown coronavirus
story: ALL hail the computer wizards. We’ve known for months that a widespread contact-tracing program is the key to easing draconian lockdown measures safely.And thanks to a swanky new app, such a weapon could be rolled out across the UK in as little as three weeks’ time.Now politicians and the public must pull together to make it a success.The efficacy of contact-tracing hinges on the existence of widely accessible, free testing — so it is welcome news that Health Secretary Matt Hancock has ramped up testing this week.But his government colleagues must explain in detail exactly how our privacy is to be protected, or risk the app going down like a lead balloon with the liberty-loving British public.After that, the ball is in our court.For the program to work, million Brits — that’s  per cent of the population — will need to download the technology and use it properly.Let’s hope and pray we are up to the challenge.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal. LOCKDOWN spring cleaners: your moment has come.After holding out for weeks, ministers have bowed to pressure and permitted councils to reopen rubbish tips. Now, the country’s , garden centres should be allowed to follow suit.We know plants aren’t essential in the strictest sense of the word. But six gruelling weeks of lockdown have left us crying out for physical activities which lt the spirits.Gardening ticks that box admirably. And even for those without the luxury of outdoor space, flowers in a window box may ease lockdown blues a little.Yes, there are risks attached to lting any restriction.But social-distancing in outdoor centres is relatively easy, so let’s get our green fingers back — it’s about blooming time.BORIS Johnson’shas put the wind in the Government’s sails.Testing numbers are rising, businesses are accessing cash, and we are seeing the vague outline of an exit strategy.But still the PPE crisis rages.We have no doubt that getting clothing manufactured and delivered is a logistical nightmare.But there have been repeated stories of manufacturers approaching the Cabinet Office to offer their services in manufacturing PPE only to be drowned in bureaucracy or not answered at all.That is not good enough.Nor is our reliance on deliveries from abroad, which never seem to make it on time.This country has already lost  key workers in the line of duty. autocrats MO since becoming Supreme Leader of North Korea in , ruthlessly protecting his own interests by executing members of his own family and allowing over  million people to starve.What the state title: lockdown not ready lifted sturgeon boris
story: Despite a massive PR operation last week to lay out options for how Scotland could come out of lockdown, the SNP leader last night suggested no changes were incoming.In veiled language last week she said the public needed to be treated like grown ups and suggested several ways measures could be eased including seeing people in bubbles of ten friends.But now shes had to row back on her words and say nothing will change anytime soon.She told ITV last night: People talk about lting the lockdown, that is not going to be a flick of the switch moment - were going to have to be very careful, very slow, very gradual.Im far from convinced at this stage that when we get to the next review point on the th of May well be in a position to lt any of these measures right now, because the margins of manoeuvre that were operating in right now are very, very, very tight and narrow.This lunchtime she echoed the same sentiment, telling Scots: Right now, that need to deliver tough messages means I have to be straight with you that it may very well be too early, even this time next week, in any meaningful way, to safely lt any of the current restrictions.She added: We are not confident the R number is very far below one yet, meaning that the rate of transmission is still just around one person passing it to another.On eight separate days this month more than , people died of the virus.Ms Sturgeon this week also recommended that Scots wear masks on public transport and in other public spaces where they cant keep a distance - but the UK hasnt changed its guidance yet.The Prime Minister is hosting Cabinet this morning one day after the birth of his son, where his team will discuss how to manage the lockdown.He is then expected to rule out any relaxing of the measures and urge Brits to stick with it when he s to the Downing Street press conferences later today.The government’s top scientists have warned the PM that easing up on the restrictions now is still very high risk.A senior No source said: “He’ll talk about the progress we’ve made so far in slowing the spread of the virus, and how we won’t do anything that might risk ato exponential growth”.Mr Johnson’s first public grilling since histo No has been designed to set the scene ahead of the lockdown’s next three week review point on May .Allies say Boris is desperate to dampen down expectations among some Tory MPs and party donors for major changes, instead opting for a “caution first” approach - especially while the lockdown is still widely supported by the public.While more Brits are urged toto workit is safe, and households could be given the opportunity to socialise with one other household group, it is now expected that much of the nation’s virtual house arrest will remain in place in May.Speaking on Monday, the PM warned Brits against lockdown impatience as the country is at the stage of maximum risk.In a rallying cry from outside No, the PM warned the nation he would refuse to risk a second wave of coronavirus cases by lting restrictions too soon, as he came back to work for the first time since his own battle with the virus.He said: Now is not the time to go easy on those social distancing measures.I ask you to contain your impatience because I believe we are coming now to the end of the first phase of this conflict.The PM said he would lay out plans to move to the next phase of the lockdown in the coming days, but warned Brits not to expect an exact date.We simply cannot spell out now how fast or slow or even when those changes will be made, he stressed.He suggested that things could move very slowly, saying measures may be changed one by one to fire up the engines of this vast UK economy.Yesterday Dominic Raab warned UK hopes of lting any lockdown measures could be hit by a possible second wave of cases in Germany.He said: This issue of a second spike and the need to avoid it – it’s not a theoretical risk, and it is not confined to the UK.Having relaxed restrictions in Germany over the past week, they have seen a rise in the transmission rate of coronavirus.And Chancellor Merkel has said publicly, and she has made it clear, that they might need a second lockdown in Germanythe infection rate continues to rise.

title: coronavirus uk live update
story: PRIME MINISTER Boris Johnson chaired his first press briefing in a month yesterday and promised to share an extensive plan to end the lockdown next week.Mr Johnson - who was at Carrie Symonds side as she gave birth to their son on Wednesday - is delaying paternity leave to help in the battle against coronavirus.The PM said the UK is now past the peak of coronavirus but braced Brits for more weeks of lockdown.It came as the UKs death toll reached , on Thursday - up by more than .Follow our coronavirus live blog below for all the latest news and updates...Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates has said that the United States and the rest of the world could have done a better job preventing the massive impact of the coronavirus pandemic.#If you used January and February properly and did community testing, you didnt have to go through this horric economic cost,# Gates set in a town hall on CNN.Previously, Gates wrote that although it would have cost billions to be better prepared, such a figure is small compared to the US defense budget.According to the -year-old billionaire, the cost of preparing and stockpiling would be around five percent of the defense budget.Specially decorated postboxes have been created by the Royal Mail as a way of thanking NHS workers for their efforts during the current crisis.The five postboxes are painted blue and bear the message: #Thank You NHS.#They are located close to St Thomas Hospital in London, Trafford General Hospital in Manchester, Royal Edinburgh Hospital, University Hospital of Wales in Cardf and The Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast.During the pandemic, its essential that you take good care of your body, as well as your mind, while staying at home.During covid, it#s essential to take care of your mind as well as your body while staying at home. infections have been documented.US President Donald Trump said on Thursday he was confident the coronavirus may have originated in a Chinese virology lab, but declined to describe the evidence for the theory.In what will be viewed as the leader ratcheting up tensions with Beijing over the origins of the deadly disease. title: stunning victorian mansion john lewis monty penguin christmas sale
story: The house in Surreys Kingston-Upon-Thames has just been listed by Savills estate agent with an asking price of £.million.The ad, which tells the story of a boy and his lonely penguin, was filmed at the property for  days with the crew even painting the house in John Lewis green.No other homes we used in that years Christmas advert.The Surrey property has had other starring roles, including the Great British Bake Off where the kitchen was used, while other parts of the property were used by Ford for advertising campaigns.The detached home extends across four levels with two living rooms and a kitchen on the ground floor.There are five bedrooms on the first floor and a separate basement.On the top floor is a space that is currently being used as a classroom and has enough tables and chairs to accommodate more than a dozen children.The loft would be ideal space for home-schooling kids during the current lockdown.

title: chinese man snakes lungs riddled worms
story: Disturbing footage shows one of the medical team pointing to, line-shaped infections on the mans lungs on the man’s CT scans.The man - identied in local media reports by his surname Wang - experienced breathing dficulties for several months before seeking treatment at a hospital in Suqian, Jiangsu province of eastern China.He was later diagnosed with paragonimiasis, a food-borne parasitic infection caused by lung fluke.He later told doctors he enjoyed eating exotic creatures and confessed that he once even gobbled down a raw snake gallbladder.Respiratory specialist Dr Zhao Haiyan hospital told local media paragonimiasis is mainly caused by eating raw seafood that contains tapeworm eggs or drinking unclean water.The sale of exotic animals at so–called Wet markets in China has been linked to the spread of the coronavirus.Wet markets traditionally sell fresh produce and live animals, such as fish and exotic animals, which are butchered in the open air.They tend to be popular with shoppers who believe the items on sale are cheaper and fresher than in supermarkets.Earlier this month it emerged that China once again selling meat from the controversial markets.Wuhan, in Hubei province celebrated the end of its strictly enforced, months-long lockdown, with China state TV showing its contentious food markets reopening to customers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccanns parents appalled despicable trolls
story: Kate and Gerry McCann are said to be disgusted by the cruel dig shared just days after the th anniversary of their daughters disappearance.The post infers Maddie, who disappeared on a family holiday in Portugal in , is dead and they are to blame.It features an old snap of heart doctor Gerry and ex-GP Kate during one of their public appeals and has been Photoshopped with them holding a placard bearing the Prime Minister’s coronavirus lockdown slogan.A family friend said: Kate and Gerry are appalled that someone could stoop this low.“To mock them like this is callous and offensive and at a time when lives are tragically being lost due to coronavirus makes it even worse.“They try to avoid social media for this very reason. The trolling has been going on for nearly  years and they find it despicable.Kate, , now a medical worker, and Gerry, , from Rothley, Leics, both work for the NHS which is being lauded during the Covid- pandemic.The mum-of-three has previously told how the hurtful abuse has been “shocking, striking and quite hard to get your head around”.The latest wave comes just months after they were left “shocked and saddened” when a troll posing as Maddie attacked them for simply eating out at a restaurant with family.Kate and Gerry were pictured by a member of public during a visit to a restaurant in Scotland in November last year.A troll later posted a Facebook jibe under a photo of the pair saying: Mum and dad are closer than I thought.”It was sickeningly in reference to the night Maddie vanished after being left sleeping alone with her younger twin siblings while her parents were dining in a nearby tapas restaurant in Portugal’s Praia da Luz in May .The McCanns were also bombarded with abuse after streaming giant Netflix released an eight-part documentary last Spring re-examining the facts of Maddie’s abduction and presenting new theories.Kate and Gerry refused to take part in the programme saying it would “do absolutely nothing” to help the global search to find her and could even hinder it.An annual prayer gathering to remember the world’s most famous missing child on Sunday has already been cancelled because of the coronavirus crisis.Kate and Gerry have been forced to axe the popular annual service for the first time but are still asking local villagers and well-wishers to come together remotely to mark the poignant occasion.The family will be sharing prayers and readings online as they spend the day behind closed doors at their home.Normally they walk a mile from their house to the village war memorial, where over the past years many supporters have congregated for the informal outdoor event.A candle still burns around the clock as a beacon of hope for Maddie.Maddie’s great uncle, Brian Kennedy, , said: “Present circumstances make our usual gathering impossible so it will all have to be done at long distance.“We are asking members of our own churches here in Rothley as well as some others to remember the day with some short prayers and readings via email and the ious internet sites.British cops have requested new funding to continue the search for Maddie which is set to be approved by the Home Office.Family spokesman Clarence Mitchell said: “It is good news that the Met Police are seeking a new budget to continue the hunt for Madeleine. Kate and Gerry are greatly encouraged that officers still believe there is active work left to be done.“Whilst an active investigation is ongoing it gives them hope that one day they will find out what happened to their daughter after all these years. The Met has a iron will determination to find the answers Kate and Gerry so desperately want.”

title: what does bame mean
story: With the terms wide usage in the media and politics, here is all you need to know about its origin and who falls under the group.BAME means Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic.It is used to describe all ethnic groups with the exception of White ethnic groups.This includes iniduals of mixed ethnicities.An inidual who identies as mixed also falls under the BAME category.It is often incorrectly assumed that BAME only refers to Black and Asian people.BAME people, according to the Government include:The most recent UK census in  shows that there are . million people from BAME backgrounds.This represents . per cent who identy as being from ethnic minorities.In , the percentage of BAME people in the census was  per cent.A study published by the University of Leeds predicts people from BAME backgrounds will make up one-fth of the UK population by .The term BME is another iation of the term which means Black Minority Ethnic.Ethnic origin is identied by a specic history, ancestry, language and culture shared by a group of people.Race is defined as an umbrella term used to describe aspects of a person’s identity that is generally linked to their own or their ancestor’s homeland, according to the Government.The term was first used in the s during the anti racist movement.According to the BBC, it has its origins from the idea of  political blackness.Professor Ted Cantle, who was the chairman of a government review of community cohesion told the BBC the terms origin stems from a time when a group of dferent ethnicities came together to fight against discrimination.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctor dad of three coronavirus
story: A FEARLESS NHS doctor died of coronavirus after telling colleagues not to be afraid and to treat patients wholeheartedly.Dr Nasir Khan, , an acute medical unit consultant who worked at Dewsbury and District Hospital in West Yorkshire, died this week after falling ill about a month ago.The hero dad-of-three was admitted to the Royal Bolton Hospital, Greater Manchester, on April  after contracting Covid .A GoFundMe page for the doctors we, , two sons, aged  and , and -year-old daughter, has raised more than £, already.Colleagues described Dr Khan, who lived in Bolton, as an extremely caring, dedicated and hardworking doctor who was the heart and soul of the ward.He had worked at Mid Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust as a locum doctor for six months.The Union Jack has been  flying at half-mast at Dewsbury Hospital as a mark of respect as family and friends paid tribute to him.His son, Mahad Ali Khan, said his dad was a loving, caring and much-loved father, husband, son, brother and friend who dedicated his le to his family and profession.Mahad Ali Khan said: He was incredibly strong and we always turned to him for support, as he was a shining light of guidance.He was compassionate, humble and loyal. He had always put his family and friends before himself and was extremely giving.He would always look for the slightest of excuses to help those in need.His hard-working nature and charming personality allowed him to make le even more enjoyable.We strive to achieve the greatness that was my dad and fulfill the dreams he has left behind. Miss you dad!The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.It comes as the UKs coronavirus death toll rose to ,, today, an increase of  in  hours.More than  NHS and care home workers have now died with coronavirus.Dr Khans friend, Dr Khalid Riaz, , a consultant ophthalmologist at Blackpool Hospital, told Sun Online Dr Khan was on a ventilator for around two weeks after contracting Covid-.He described his former next-door neighbour and colleague as very fit and believes he caught the deadly bug while treating Covid- patients.Dr Riaz told Sun Online: He was working very devotedly with the patients after this outbreak.“He kept telling colleagues and juniors, “Don’t be afraid of coronavirus, continue working, you don’t have to be afraid of death. We have to treat these patients’.He was working without any break.He was staying onsite and his colleagues were telling me he would keep calling even in the night and the evening, ‘How is that patient, how is this patient’.He was very worried about his patients.Dr Khan, originally from Pakistan, developed symptoms at the start of April and self-isolated before going to hospital.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Dr Riaz said the doctors family is devastated at his death.He has set up the GoFundMe page and hopes to raise £, with all the money raised going to Dr Khans family and the future education of his three children.Dr Riaz added: It is very sad. We are very upset, obviously all the community.He was very lovely, and a very jolly man.”Martin Barkley, Chief Executive of The Mid Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, paid tribute to Dr Khans fantastic leadership as someone who was absolutely dedicated to the well-being of the junior staff he was working with.Mr Barkley added: We consider ourselves very fortunate to have had such a doctor as Dr Khan working for the Trust, and we are all devastated to learn of his death.It is impossible to put into words how much our hearts go out to his family and friends.“This news is a terrible reminder of the consequences of this pandemic that so many families are having to face.To donate to Dr Khans family please visit the GoFundMe page here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.[ boxout]Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: us cities rare maps new york washington dc
story: The full-color illustrations show some of the countrys greatest cities in their earlier days, including New York, Los Angeles, Boston, and the nations capital of Washington D.C.One map features the famous Washington Monument - then only eight years old - while another displays the proposed site of the famed  Worlds Exposition fair celebrating industrial development.So, can you guess them all Map printing came about in the mid-th century after American inventor Richard March Hoe created the first rotary press in .His creation brought the United States closer to achieving mass print production.But it wasnt until the early s that illustrations became a staple of magazines and other print publications.As such, the vibrant vintage maps were and still are a rarity.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris rules out austerity coronavirus
story: THE Prime Minister tonight said there will be NOto austerity as the UK recovers from the effects of the coronavirus lockdown.Boris Johnson said he believes the countrys economy will bounce back strongly after his Government offered an extensive package of financial support to help Brits during the pandemic.During Downing Streets daily press conference on the coronavirus crisis, ITVs Robert Peston questioned the economic toll of Chancellor Rishi Sunaks package of support for struggling businesses.He asked the Prime Minister: Because of the unprecedented help youre giving to struggling iniduals and business, national debt is rising by hundreds of millions of pounds, a record amount in peacetime.How great a risk is there that when we are through this crisis you will feel compelled to cut public services and move us into a new era of austerity Mr Johnson replied: I think the economy will bounce back strongly.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.I think that this government will want to encourage that bounce back in all kinds of ways - but Ive never particularly liked the term [austerity] that youve just used to describe government economic policy, and its certainly not going to be part of our approach.It comes after Mr Johnson tonight said the UK is past the peak of the crisis.There are , people in hospital at the moment battling with the disease. In total, , have now died.However, Mr Johnson said: For the first time we are past the peak of this disease. We are past the peak and on downwards slope.We have so many reasons to be hopeful for the long term.But he cautioned against lting the lockdown too early in case it leads to a second wave.We have come through the peak - or rather weve come under what could have been a vast peak, as though weve been going through some vast alpine tunnel, and we can now see the sunlight and the pasture ahead of us, he said.It is vital that we dont lose control and run slap into a second and bigger mountain.Today, we reported that Europe is suffering its worst financial crisis since World War II as France and Italy plunge into recession and Spains economy collapses.Latest figures today show the European economy shrank by a record . per cent in the first quarter of the year.And former Bank of England rate-setter Ian McCafferty says Britain will be paying for action to save the economy for the next two decades.Experts predicted at the beginning of the month that the lockdown is costing £.billion a day.Former Prime Minister David Cameron and his Chancellor George Osborne instigated a policy of public spending reductions to save the economy after it was crashed by Labour in .The cuts, which were dubbed austerity measures, meant some services and big projects were scaled back after borrowing soared under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.Mr Johnson vowed to end a decade of austerity before he won the Brexit election last year.Last November, he revealed the Conservatives election manesto ahead of the election, vowing to support working men and women.He promised to tear up austerity and turn the spending taps on.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.

title: lockdown time think about freedom
story: LONDON’S Millennium Bridge connecting the busy South Bank with the busier City on Monday, April , .There was not a soul in sight at .pm on my daily Government-sanctioned walk home from the talkRADIO studio.It was the same scene in the once-bustling theatre district of Covent Garden and as I wandered past the usually-heaving Holborn Station on to Fleet Street, where the pubs are now boarded up and there’s an eerie still in the air made more  Days Later-like by the unusually loud seagulls craving food.Our unrivalled capital city, which survived the great fire, the Blitz, the IRA, al-Qaeda and IS, has been temporarily silenced for the greater good.So why is it that any time I switch on the internet or social media I’m bombarded with negativity about how the UK — and London in particular — has failed during lockdown I’ve had it with this untrue, unfair and frankly offensive narrative being spewed by out-of-touch, Government-hating journalists and publicity-hungry Twitter commentators.Their only evidence  Harmless pictures showing families sitting down in the middle of a park enjoying an ice cream, folk going for a bike ride on a sunny day and even police officers gathering to clap for the NHS on Westminster Bridge in a show of national unity.The reality, of course, is that the vast majority of us are respecting the rules, at great personal and financial cost. After days of hysterical commentary about increased car usage, the official slides at the Government briefing this week showed it had actually gone down.Is it any wonder that trust in telly journalists, with their constant gotcha questions of ministers and desire to do down our national effort, is plummeting So let me say this in Britain’s biggest newspaper that has maintained the loyalty of our brilliant army of readers with hysteria-free coverage: We have done so well and all deserve to be applauded for our stoic efforts to flatten the curve.Even at the start of March, nobody could have imagined that the UK would spend six weeks without the Premier League, McDonald’s or nightclubs Let alone losing those joys of our national le at a time when everyone other than key workers had to stay at home.You’ve missed weddings, births, signicant birthdays, important operations and even funerals. That’s why I am so proud of the citizens of this country.Do not let anyone tell you that the UK didn’t take this evil disease seriously. We did. Unquestionably.But that doesn’t mean we should now stay silent and accept a continued loss of our freedom and liberties. Our first goal is achieved: We avoided the NHS being overrun.Demanding answers from our leaders about what’s next and how we reopen our country does not for a single second make you disloyal — it makes you even more of a patriot.THE Greatest Dancer has been axed by the BBC.Which is bad news for star judge Cheryl Tweedy, who doesn’t seem to enjoy the same bankability she did at the height of her X Factor glory days .But good news for Girls Aloud fans like me as every solo flop just makes the reunion even more inevitable.lIn other exciting girl band news, the Spice Girls are in talks to do another world reunion tour.SADIQ KHAN has done so alarm-ingly little to help Londoners during this crisis – no masks, no sanitisers or PPE on public transport – that it might be time for the London Mayor to consider changing his name to Sadiq Can’t.MY love letter to the things I never thought I’d miss living in London . . .ONCE upon a time there lived a celebrity journalist called Omid Scobie.He revelled in the sort of nonsense that used to fill the pages of Star Magazine, one of the UK’s most downmarket celeb titles.For many years, until very recently, Mr Scobie also flogged story after story to popular newspapers about celebs and the royals, including the Mail on Sunday.Nothing wrong with that so far. But I’m just surprised that it’s this fellow hack who notoriously tabloid-hating Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has picked to write her hagiography, I mean, biography of her “horror” couple of years title: russian prime minister positive coronavirus
story: RUSSIAS Prime Minister has been struck down with coronavirus, it has been announced tonight.Mikhail Mishustin says he has tested positive for Covid- - and he has told President Vladimir Putin he will self-isolate.Speaking during a televised meeting, Mishustin said: I have to observe self-isolation and follow orders of doctors.This is is necessary to observe self-isolation and follow orders of doctors.This is necessary to protect my colleagues.First Deputy Prime Minister Andrei Belousov will temporarily perform Mishustins duties.It comes as Covid- spreads to all  of Russias regions.Pressure is mounting on the government to consider easing lockdown restrictions to help businesses as the vast countrys economy struggles with the blow.Russia, the worlds largest country by territory, has been on lockdown since Mr Putin announced the closure of most public spaces in late March.These measures were due to expire today, but no announcement on the countrys future plans has yet been made.Mishustin, , was named prime minister in January, making him the head of the Russian government and the second most powerful figure in the Russian Federation, after the president.Putin said on Tuesday it was likely the lockdown would extend for at least two more weeks, as he continued to urge Russians to stay home.On Thursday, Russias total number of reported coronavirus cases surpassed the , mark, exceeding numbers reported from Iran and China.There have been , deaths.Of  coronavirus hotspots the country is trying to contain,  per cent are in hospitals.It comes weeks after UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson was hospitalised after contracting the virus.He battled for his le in intensive care before being discharged - and has this week ed to Downing Street.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.

title: weather spring sunshine return 17c
story: But forecasters are hopeful that after five days of squalls and chilly temperatures, the sunshine willthis weekend - and there could be highs of C.Last week, we saw highs of C - making the UK hotter than Malaga.But that all ended on Monday as the mercury plunged to around C.Officials warned that a weather cell blowing in from the Atlantic would cause power showers - and the rain would go on into May.However, as we draw near to the end of April, it looks like weve been granted a reprieve.The Met Office is now predicting settled, warmer weather for the beginning of next month, although we can still expect some showers, and itll be much cooler than last week.Emma Falter of the Met Office said: It looks set to generally improve quite slowly.Tomorrow and through the weekend, the weather will start to get a bit warmer - itll be around C at the absolute highest.By Wednesday well be getting back up to around C.Itll be a bit cheerier and therell be more sunshine around.Average temperatures for May are usually around C, she said.Asked whether we could see ato the warm days of last week, she said theres a dferent beast driving the weather over the UK.Aprils sunshine was caused by a high pressure system from the continent - but recently weve faced the opposite, with low pressure systems bringing in colder weather and lots of rain.Sunny spells Saturday with showers in the north and east.Cloudy with rain in the far south Sunday, sunny spells where with showers in the north.Most places fine Monday.

title: cactus fruit cocktail best hangover cure
story: It was able to halve rates of sickness and reduce headache pain by a third.The cactus fruit cocktail helped the body cleanse itself of booze faster than any other remedy.The researchers also dismissed the idea that dehydration is behind some of the most common symptoms of the morning after the night before.The findings come from a German study in which volunteers gulped down alcohol.Those given a drink containing extracts from cherries, prickly pears or cactus fruit, ginkgo biloba, willow and ginger root had milder hangovers.Polyphenol and flavonoid compounds in the five plant extracts have been linked with curbing the effects of alcohol in experimental studies. But its not clear how.Various natural remedies have been recommended to ease hangover symptoms, but there is as yet no strong scientic evidence for their use.A full English breakfast, a big cup of coffee or even drinking more alcohol - the list of touted hangover cures is forever growing.So the researchers assessed the potential of specic plant extracts, vitamins and minerals, and antioxidant compounds to ease a range of recognised physical and psychological symptoms associated with drinking alcohol.But researcher Professor Bernard Lieb said: “The underlying mechanisms remain to be unravelled.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: reopen schools experts clash
story: EXPERTS have clashed over whether children can pass on Covid- — as the Government battles to get schools open by summer.First, Swiss researchers said youngsters posed no threat of infection because they do not have the lung receptors targeted by the virus.But within  hours a review of Chinese cases and a German study suggested they were just as likely to catch it as adults.The conflicting research comes as the Government is facing growing pressure, with ministers hoping to get classrooms reopened before the summer holidays.There are fears thousands of vulnerable youngsters will be left behindschools do not reopen in some form soon.And many MPs believe getting children back into classrooms is vital to kick-starting the battered UK economy by freeing parents to work.Yet, the studies will only serve to reinforce ministers’ grave doubts about acting too quickly.On Wednesday, Switzerland had offered the UK a glimmer of hope of an early lockdown exit.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Dr Daniel Koch, head of the infectious diseases unit at the Federal Office of Public Health, told reporters in Berne that the under- tens with no symptoms could freely hug their grandparents again.He added: “Children are very rarely infected and do not pass on the virus. That is why small children pose no risk to high-risk patients or grandparents.”The research followed a French study which showed a nine-year-old British boy who caught the virus while skiing had not passed it on despite contact with  others.Hopes rose further when Education Secretary Gavin Williamson told MPs he was looking at plans for children in Years ,  and  toto school first.But doubts were quickly cast on the Swiss research by British medics.Prof Russell Viner, president of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said: “We don’t think that it would be a good idea for children to hug their grandparents in the UK without more data.“We think that children probably transmit Covid- less than adults.“But we need to be sure — and we would need to have a lot more data, particularly because grandparents are in the vulnerable group.”That caution has been echoed by the US-Chinese study looking at , close contacts of  people infected in the province of Shenzhen.Of those, seven per cent of young children caught the virus — the same proportion as in adults and older children. But most children displayed no symptoms.Prof Simon Clarke, of the University of Reading, told The Times: “This is an important paper. It means we should be extremely careful.“Reopening schools could expose parents, grandparents and teachers to infection and anyone they might come into contact with, risking a second wave.”Tom Wingfield, of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, said: “We should definitely consider children as a pool for infection.“In terms of what it means for transmission rates though, the honest answer is, we still don’t know definitively.“Given they are less symptomatic, we can at least suspect they are not spraying out as much with coughing and sneezing.”Last night, the German study of , patients also found no signicant dference between young and old. It concluded: “Based on these results, we have to caution against an unlimited re-opening of schools and kindergartens at present.”But Dr Ebere Okereke, of Public Health England, added to confusion by saying younger children were less likely to be affected and — unlike with the flu — less likely to be transmitters.She added: “Traditionally, we associate children as people transmitting respiratory infections. This doesn’t seem to be the case here. And why is this dferent  We don’t know.”THESE reports do not alter the debate about whether or not children shouldto school.It is a balance of risks. Keeping pupils at home will damage their education, cause mental health problems, language problems and increase the gap between the rich and the poor.Yet, allowing pupils to go back risks a second pandemic waveit is not done carefully.What we need to do is get as many children as possible back into education.We could split year groups into mornings or afternoons only or they could do one week on and one week off to cut down social contact.When the Government does relax the lockdown, probably the safest group to be out there is children. So ministers should plan for the reopening of schools to start early in the exit.The swine flu outbreak of  dropped like a stone when the schools broke up for summer. Then, within a few weeks of the schools going back, we had a second wave of the disease.It is important to say there is a lot of conflicting evidence. The Swiss government, for example, took evidence from scientists and concluded children under ten do not transmit the virus.But the truth is we do not yet know enough about this virus. I would argue it is better to err on the side of caution. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british scientists coronavirus vaccine mid june
story: BRITISH scientists working on a coronavirus vaccine have said they will know by early summerit works.Human trials of the Oxford University jab began last week.Now, the team has struck a deal with pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca for a huge roll-out of the vaccine at cost price.The company has pledged to produce million doses this yearthe trials prove positive.And it has promised to put the UK at the front of the queue for early access to millions of jabs.Sir John Bell, Regius Professor of Medicine at Oxford University, said several hundred volunteers had already been given the experimental injection.He said the team should get a “signal about whether its working by the middle of June”.A successful vaccine is crucial to ending restrictions and le ing to normal.Lead researcher on the Oxford project Professor Sarah Gilbert has previously said she is  per cent confident it will succeed.Sir John told the BBC Today programme the partnership with AstraZeneca would ensure it could be rolled out quickly.He said: “Once we get an approval by the regulators, we don’t want to have to go back to the beginning and work out how we manufacture it at scale.“We also want to make sure that the rest of the world will be ready to make this vaccine at scale so that it gets to populations in developing countries where the need is very great.”Plans are in place to keep million doses for vulnerable Brits.CAN we get a vaccine Research to find a vaccine is happening continuously, with around  studies around the globe. Trials need to show the vaccine is safe.WHAT’S the UK doing A potential vaccine being developed at the University of Oxford has begun its human trials — the first in Europe.HOW will it be produced The Oxford study has linked up with UK pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca to mass produce the potential vaccine on a not-for-profit basis for the duration of the pandemic.WHEN will one be available Most experts reckon by mid- but the Oxford team are saying they will knowtheirs works by this summer.IS there a drug to treat the coronavirus Early results of a US trial suggest antiviral drug remdesivir cuts the number of days patients take to leave hospital by almost a third.HOW does it work Remdesivir, originally developed to treat Ebola, targets a cell enzyme the virus needs.IS it a game changer Potentially. Dr Anthony Fauci, leading member of the US coronavirus task force, said: “What it has proven is that a drug can block this virus.” But a second trial in China showed no benefit.WHO is looking for a drug cure There are around  clinic trials going on worldwideAstraZeneca boss Pascal Soriot said investment in the vaccine was a risk worth taking — and said it would be supplied at cost price throughout the pandemic.And he said million doses could be produced this year.He said: “It is definitely a risk to launch into development of this vaccine, but now is the time to take those risks — this is a terrible crisis we’re facing and we need solutions.“And a vaccine, of course, is the number one tool we can bring to manage this epidemic.“We should know relatively soonit does work. By June or July we will already have a pretty good idea of direction of travel in terms of its potential efficacy.”The jab involves a weakened version of the common cold containing some of the genetic material from Covid-.It works by getting the body to make a protein found on the surface of the bug.Experts think this should provoke an immune response against the virus — protecting the inidual from becoming sick.Professor Robin Shattock, who is leading a team at Imperial College London developing a rival vaccine, welcomed the deal.He said: “This is an encouraging development. We need to make sure UK vaccines are made readily available.”Health Secretary Matt Hancock said it was “hugely welcome news” Oxford University had come to an agreement with AstraZeneca to scale up its coronavirus vaccine.He tweeted: “The Oxford vaccine is one of the most advanced in the world. Bringing together the best British science and the best of British business will give us the best possible shot at a vaccine.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.“The science is uncertain, and no vaccine may work, but this deal gives the UK the best chance we can of a breakthrough that could defeat this awful virus.”Professor David Salisbury, former director of immunisation at the Department of Health, commented: “If the Oxford vaccine is shown to be safe and effective by the end of the year, and the UK could access million doses at that time, then this would be of extraordinary importance in protecting our population — assuming that each person requires two doses.“If the UK only accessed million doses by the same time, even that would be of huge benefit for the at-risk iniduals, health and social care and other essential service workers.”Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits make pubs garden lockdown
story: WHILE the country thirsts for pubs to re-open, some people have been heading to the boozer during the Covid- crisis without breaking the law – having had the foresight to build their own bars in sheds, garages or patio party zones.And just because the emergency regulations mean their mates can’t join them, it doesn’t stop these home pubgoers being social – with some of them holding quizzes or even parties over the internet.So as Wetherspoons boss Tim Martin gave hope to millions of others by saying he would reopen the chain next month, this cheerful lot have long since been sinking pints and knocking back shorts without a care in the world.The amateur landlords and landladies don’t even need a licence as long as they don’t take payment for any of the booze.Seven garden pub owners tell Grant Rollings how they created a place for a lock-in in lockdown.WHEN Kieran Gillingham’s local shut five years ago, he decided to create his own.Kieran, , who is employed by the Environment Agency, said: “I built it using the old wood I pulled from the rivers while working.”The Fisherman’s Rest, which was shortlisted for the  Cuprinol Shed of the Year, can fit in  people – but only Kieran, partner KimDawkins and their -year-old twins Kayley and Kane get to enjoy the pub during lockdown.Fishing fan Kieran, from Winchester, Hants, said of the fully stocked bar: “I styled it to suit my personality.”ONE mum’s shed-based pub quiz has gone global since we were told to stay home.Katie King, , from Radclfe, Greater Manchester, started a Saturday night brain teaser for a bit of lockdown fun.Now there are  teams taking part from as far away as Australia.Katie, a travel worker who this week had her birthday in the bar they call the King’s Head, said: “It gave us a reason to dress up on a Saturday night.”Hubby Richard, , a police- man, did the conversion. Katie said: “We planned to have friends round, instead it’s a great place to escape to with a glass of red wine during isolation.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.WITH no matches on, rugby pro Gareth Steenson cleared his garage to make a weekend haven.The -year-old, from Exeter, who plays for Premiership side The Chiefs said: “I had a spare fridge, which I put the beers in. Then I started to put in the sports memorabilia I had collected.”Gareth is home schooling sons William, five, and Oscar, seven, while his we Karen, , a GP, is still working.He said: “With lockdown I cleared out the clutter and it’s now the perfect spot for us to relax on a Friday night.”RETIRED foundry worker Steve Worrallo is still going to his pub every night – even though the regulars can’t join him.Divorcee Steve, from Cannock, Staffs, built his boozer in his shed from scratch.It has a disco glitter ball, mock Tudor beams, hundreds of records on the ceiling, a dance floor and a sign from the Corn Exchange out- side.But the pumps are just for show, as Steve is happy to drink a can of lager.Steve is considered vulnerable to Covid- because he is , so even his two sons, Dane, , and Brett, , are not allowed to share a pint.But Steve said: “It is still great to have a pub in the garden. Coming out here is a change from staying in the house.”USING old wooden pallets, dad Graham Storrie turned part of his garden into a trendy outdoor bar for his daughter’s th birthday two years ago.Graham, , a print finisher who lives with we Gillian, , in Prestonpans, East Lothian, said of his creation: “I winged it. I had no guide or plan.“There was an unused space in the garden with a big rock, which I tidied up, then I built on it.”His younger daughter Abbie will celebrate her th birthday in July andgatherings are still banned because of the pandemic, Graham says his design will come in handy again.He said: “We had a venue booked for Abbie’s birthday but we might need the garden bar instead.”WITH its own jukebox and sound system, Matt Oakley’s garden boozer has helped him party through the lockdown.Matt, a construction contract manager from Leverstock Green, Herts, has listened to live DJs via the internet and linked up with pals on video app Zoom.The -year-old, who is married to Hayley, , started kitting out the pre-fab log cabin just before Christmas.He said: “I was so pleased to get it finished before lockdown.“It has been a le saver.“We have been getting the drinks in and dressing up for themed parties with friends over Zoom.”ELECTRICIAN Paddy Riordan has recreated Sally O’Brien’s, a favourite bar in New York.The -year-old, of Staplehurst, Kent, said: “It’s based on an Irish pub in the US. I bought a nice lump of cedar and made the bar myself. The wine cooler came from a local pub that closed and I put in proper pumps.”Unfortunately there is no beer attached to them at present, but that doesn’t stop the enjoyment for Paddy, his we Mandy, , and Megan, , the youngest of their four daughters.He completed the bar in September and it can fit up to  people.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cambodian sole trader sells shoes motorcycle
story: Hundreds of pairs of shoes are strapped to his motorbike and cart as he tries to sell them in the capital, Phnom Pehn.But he may not be able to do this for much longer - as the Cambodian government is about to introduce stricter traffic laws in an effort to cut down traffic accidents in the country.An extra , cops will be deployed to enforce the rules - and hand out bigger fines.At least , people died and , others were injured in over , road accidents in  in the Asian nation.It comes as more than  Britons chartered their own plane back to the UK after becoming stranded in Cambodia earlier this year.After the country shut its borders amidst the coronavirus outbreak, stranded couple Jerry and Karen Lewis found themselves stuck in Cambodia after their flight home was canceled.The couple used Facebook to put together a list of  stranded UK citizens willing to cover the six-figure sum needed to charter a Malaysia Airlines flight home.They are now safely home after the flight left on th March.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk firms post lockdown plans
story: UK firms have revealed plans for how they willstaff to work after the lockdown lts.Options to slowly creep back to work after the coronavirus pandemic include staggered shts, isolated working and getting rid of cash.After Boris Johnson revealed yesterday he will have a plan on how the restrictions will end by next week, companies are preparing.It is assumed safety and distancing measures will continue in the workplace eventhe lockdown is lted.And many workforces may see a huge dference in how they interact with colleagues or use office space for months to come.The virus is expected to be a part of normal le until a vaccine is developed, which could be months away.Standard Chartered bank is thought to be keeping workers at home after the lockdown ends, while car factories may use markings to keep distances between staff.Builders could only be allowed into homes one at a time and hotel cleaners may have special zones in rooms they have to deep clean.Business Secretary Alok Sharma has requested advice is compiled from officials on how toto work gradually.It will cover seven dferent workplaces, including offices, factories and construction sites.Construction companies too scared to lose their jobsthey didnt show up.Taylor Wimpey is bringing some employees back to work next Monday, with just a handful of people on site.Sub-contractors are then thought to be in a staggeredfrom May , until  per cent of the work force is back.Crossrail work has been stopped and will continue to be paused, but HS workers have been on site throughout the lockdown.Real estate title: pubs may stay shut in londons coronavirus
story: SADIQ KHAN has warned pubs and restaurants may remain closed when Londons coronavirus lockdown is eased.The London Mayor also said in the capitals new normal commuters will have to wear masks on the Tube and workers and schools would need staggered start times to keep crowding to a minimum.He set out a bleak picture for a post-lockdown London and said that people would only be able to see their loved ones occasionally.But he demanded the public is treated as adults over the governments plans to relieve the Covid- lockdown.Writing in The Evening Standard, Mr Khan said: There will be noto le as it was – instead we face a ‘new normal’ even once lockdown is eased.We may be able to occasionally see our closest loved ones – but interactions will be limited and for a while there will be no larger gatherings.While non-essential shops will be able to reopen after introducing social distancing measures, it is dficult to see how this can safely be extended to bars, restaurants or social spaces in a practicable way soon.He said start times for schools and workplaces would have to be staggered throughout the day to reduce crowds in rush hour and that working from home must continue where possible.People travelling on public transport are likely to have to wear non-medical face coverings to reduce the risk to others, he said.The stark warning comes as Britains death toll rose on Thursday to , after another  people died from the virus.Boris Johnson, speaking at the daily Downing Street press conference for the first time since he fell ill with the virus, said he will set out a plan next week to kickstart the economy, get kids back to school and find a way to make workplaces safer.But most Londoners now working from home will need to continue doing so for the foreseeable future, Mr Khan believes.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.The capitals transport system faces specic challenges under social distancing guidelines for people to stay two metres apart.And fears have been raised by emergency planners that Londons transport network could be rapidly overwhelmed by a surge of passengers.As a result, Londoners would have to walk or cycle more often, the mayor believes.Mr Khan added: People using public transport are likely to have to use non-medical face coverings to reduce the risk to others – as governments around the world and now the Scottish Government is advising.Start times for schools and workplaces will have to be staggered throughout the day to avoid a congested rush hour and limit overcrowding.He also hailed Britains resurging community spirit  and the weekly clap for carers to salute NHS and care home workers on the coronavirus frontline.But he warned of longer-term consequences of the Covid-s outbreaks financial hammer blow to Transport for London , cautioning we shouldn’t look backwards to le as it was before this virus.More than eight million Brits could be furloughed as a result of the coronavirus outbreak as millions face destitution, the mayor wrote.He called for unprecedented Government support to keep the economy moving, with the capitals nightle and tourist industry battered by a huge downturn in trade.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad finds seven inch chip
story: The -year-old was making chicken and chips for his dinner when the monster dropped out of the packet.He said: “It was absolutely massive. I turned to the missus and said, ‘Have a look at the size of this’. We were both laughing.“I decided to measure it just for a giggle. It was seven inches long.“I even measured it against a banana and my head. It was as big as the plate.”Pension manager Oliver, from York, took snaps of his find before sticking it in the oven on Tuesday.He added: “It was a pity to eat it. But that one chip alone pretty much filled me up.”Dad-of-two Oliver said he bought the £. bag of McCain frozen oven chips from Asda near his home.He now wants to find outhis chip really is a world-beater.The Guinness World Records states the largest chip was made in October  by Chandresh Bayad in Gujarat, India, and it weighed lb oz.But, unlike Oliver’s, that chip was moulded and not from a packet. There is no known record for the longest chip.In McCain’s hit ad campaign We Are Family, its narrator — Royle Family actor Ricky Tomlinson — says: “It’s dferences that make a family.”Mark Hodge, marketing director at McCain, said: “Wow, that is a big chip.“Looks like we over-delivered this time for Oliver but we’re glad to have brought so much joy to his plate.“As a family business, we know families come in all shapes and sizes. It seems the same goes for our chips.”McCain, founded in Canada in , is the UK’s largest purchaser of British potatoes, buying  per cent of the annual potato crop and working with -plus growers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
